trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Key Vault | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Key Vault | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Key Vault
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Key Vault

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault is available in most regions.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault is available in most regions.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Key Vault pricing page](../../../../pricing/details/key-vault/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Key Vault pricing page](../../../../pricing/details/key-vault/).

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container (a vault) in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use this tutorial to help you get started with Azure Key Vault to create a hardened container (a vault) in Azure, to store and manage cryptographic keys and secrets in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of using Windows PowerShell to create a vault that contains a key or password that you can then use with an Azure application.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of using Windows PowerShell to create a vault that contains a key or password that you can then use with an Azure application.

trans-unit.source: It then shows you how an application can use that key or password.
trans-unit.target: It then shows you how an application can use that key or password.

trans-unit.source: *Estimated time to complete:** 20 minutes
trans-unit.target: *Estimated time to complete:** 20 minutes

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial does not include instructions for how to write the Azure application that one of the steps includes, namely how to authorize an application to use a key or secret in the key vault.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This tutorial does not include instructions for how to write the Azure application that one of the steps includes, namely how to authorize an application to use a key or secret in the key vault.

trans-unit.source: Currently, you cannot configure Azure Key Vault in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Currently, you cannot configure Azure Key Vault in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Instead, use these Azure PowerShell instructions.
trans-unit.target: Instead, use these Azure PowerShell instructions.

trans-unit.source: Or, for Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface instructions, see [this equivalent tutorial](key-vault-manage-with-cli.md).
trans-unit.target: Or, for Cross-Platform Command-Line Interface instructions, see [this equivalent tutorial](key-vault-manage-with-cli.md).

trans-unit.source: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)
trans-unit.target: For overview information about Azure Key Vault, see [What is Azure Key Vault?](key-vault-whatis.md)

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: A subscription to Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: A subscription to Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have one, you can sign up for a [free trial](../../../../pricing/free-trial).
trans-unit.target: If you do not have one, you can sign up for a [free trial](../../../../pricing/free-trial).

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell version 0.9.1 or later.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell version 0.9.1 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: An application that will be configured to use the key or password that you create in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: An application that will be configured to use the key or password that you create in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: A sample application is available from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=45343).
trans-unit.target: A sample application is available from the [Microsoft Download Center](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=45343).

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see the accompanying Readme file.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see the accompanying Readme file.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed for Windows PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed for Windows PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see [Getting started with Windows PowerShell](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh857337.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see [Getting started with Windows PowerShell](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh857337.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the **Get-Help** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the **Get-Help** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, to get help for the **Add-AzureAccount** cmdlet, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, to get help for the **Add-AzureAccount** cmdlet, type:

trans-unit.source: You can also read the following tutorials to get familiar with Azure Resource Manager in Windows PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: You can also read the following tutorials to get familiar with Azure Resource Manager in Windows PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Connect to your subscriptions
trans-unit.target: Connect to your subscriptions

trans-unit.source: Start an Azure PowerShell session and sign in to your Azure account with the following command:
trans-unit.target: Start an Azure PowerShell session and sign in to your Azure account with the following command:

trans-unit.source: In the pop-up browser window, enter your Azure account user name and password.
trans-unit.target: In the pop-up browser window, enter your Azure account user name and password.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell will get all the subscriptions that are associated with this account and by default, uses the first one.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell will get all the subscriptions that are associated with this account and by default, uses the first one.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to specify a specific one to use for Azure Key Vault, type the following to see the subscriptions for your account:
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to specify a specific one to use for Azure Key Vault, type the following to see the subscriptions for your account:

trans-unit.source: Then, to specify the subscription to use, type:
trans-unit.target: Then, to specify the subscription to use, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring Azure PowerShell, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring Azure PowerShell, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: Switch to using Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Switch to using Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: The Key Vault cmdlets require Azure Resource Manager, so type the following to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode:
trans-unit.target: The Key Vault cmdlets require Azure Resource Manager, so type the following to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode:

trans-unit.source: Create a new resource group
trans-unit.target: Create a new resource group

trans-unit.source: When you use Azure Resource Manager, all related resources are created inside a resource group.
trans-unit.target: When you use Azure Resource Manager, all related resources are created inside a resource group.

trans-unit.source: We will create a new resource group named **ContosoResourceGroup** for this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: We will create a new resource group named **ContosoResourceGroup** for this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: For the **-Location** parameter, use the command [Get-AzureLocation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn654582.aspx) to identify how to specify an alternative location to the one in this example.
trans-unit.target: For the **-Location** parameter, use the command [Get-AzureLocation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn654582.aspx) to identify how to specify an alternative location to the one in this example.

trans-unit.source: If you need more information, type: `Get-Help Get-AzureLocation`
trans-unit.target: If you need more information, type: `Get-Help Get-AzureLocation`

trans-unit.source: Create a key vault
trans-unit.target: Create a key vault

trans-unit.source: Use the [New-AzureKeyVault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903602.aspx) cmdlet to create a key vault.
trans-unit.target: Use the [New-AzureKeyVault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903602.aspx) cmdlet to create a key vault.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet has three mandatory parameters: a **resource group name**, a **key vault name**, and the **geographic location**.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet has three mandatory parameters: a **resource group name**, a **key vault name**, and the **geographic location**.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you use the vault name of **ContosoKeyVault**, the resource group name of **ContosoResourceGroup**, and the location of **East Asia**, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you use the vault name of **ContosoKeyVault**, the resource group name of **ContosoResourceGroup**, and the location of **East Asia**, type:

trans-unit.source: The output of this cmdlet shows properties of the key vault that you’ve just created.
trans-unit.target: The output of this cmdlet shows properties of the key vault that you’ve just created.

trans-unit.source: The two most important properties are:
trans-unit.target: The two most important properties are:

trans-unit.source: **Name**: In the example, this is **ContosoKeyVault**.
trans-unit.target: **Name**: In the example, this is **ContosoKeyVault**.

trans-unit.source: You will use this name for other Key Vault cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You will use this name for other Key Vault cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: **vaultUri**: In the example, this is https://contosokeyvault.vault.azure.net/.
trans-unit.target: **vaultUri**: In the example, this is https://contosokeyvault.vault.azure.net/.

trans-unit.source: Applications that use your vault through its REST API must use this URI.
trans-unit.target: Applications that use your vault through its REST API must use this URI.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure account is now authorized to perform any operations on this key vault.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure account is now authorized to perform any operations on this key vault.

trans-unit.source: As yet, nobody else is.
trans-unit.target: As yet, nobody else is.

trans-unit.source: Add a key or secret to the key vault
trans-unit.target: Add a key or secret to the key vault

trans-unit.source: If you want Azure Key Vault to create a software-protected key for you, use the [Add-AzureKeyVaultKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn868048.aspx) cmdlet, and type the following:
trans-unit.target: If you want Azure Key Vault to create a software-protected key for you, use the [Add-AzureKeyVaultKey](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn868048.aspx) cmdlet, and type the following:

trans-unit.source: However, if you have an existing software-protected key in a .PFX file saved to your C:\ drive in a file named softkey.pfx that you want to upload to Azure Key Vault, type the following to set the variable **securepfxpwd** for a password of **123** for the .PFX file:
trans-unit.target: However, if you have an existing software-protected key in a .PFX file saved to your C:\ drive in a file named softkey.pfx that you want to upload to Azure Key Vault, type the following to set the variable **securepfxpwd** for a password of **123** for the .PFX file:

trans-unit.source: Then type the following to import the key from the .PFX file, which protects the key by software in the Key Vault service:
trans-unit.target: Then type the following to import the key from the .PFX file, which protects the key by software in the Key Vault service:

trans-unit.source: You can now reference this key that you created or uploaded to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.
trans-unit.target: You can now reference this key that you created or uploaded to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.

trans-unit.source: Use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey/cgacf4f763ar42ffb0a1gca546aygd87** to get this specific version.
trans-unit.target: Use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoKeyVault.vault.azure.net/keys/ContosoFirstKey/cgacf4f763ar42ffb0a1gca546aygd87** to get this specific version.

trans-unit.source: To display the URI for this key, type:
trans-unit.target: To display the URI for this key, type:

trans-unit.source: To add a secret to the vault, which is a password named SQLPassword and has the value of Pa$$w0rd to Azure Key Vault, first convert the value of Pa$$w0rd to a secure string by typing the following:
trans-unit.target: To add a secret to the vault, which is a password named SQLPassword and has the value of Pa$$w0rd to Azure Key Vault, first convert the value of Pa$$w0rd to a secure string by typing the following:

trans-unit.source: Then, type the following:
trans-unit.target: Then, type the following:

trans-unit.source: You can now reference this password that you added to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.
trans-unit.target: You can now reference this password that you added to Azure Key Vault, by using its URI.

trans-unit.source: Use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword/90018dbb96a84117a0d2847ef8e7189d** to get this specific version.
trans-unit.target: Use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword** to always get the current version, and use **https://ContosoVault.vault.azure.net/secrets/SQLPassword/90018dbb96a84117a0d2847ef8e7189d** to get this specific version.

trans-unit.source: To display the URI for this secret, type:
trans-unit.target: To display the URI for this secret, type:

trans-unit.source: Let’s view the key or secret that you just created:
trans-unit.target: Let’s view the key or secret that you just created:

trans-unit.source: To view your key, type: `Get-AzureKeyVaultKey –VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`
trans-unit.target: To view your key, type: `Get-AzureKeyVaultKey –VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`

trans-unit.source: To view your secret, type: `Get-AzureKeyVaultSecret –VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`
trans-unit.target: To view your secret, type: `Get-AzureKeyVaultSecret –VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`

trans-unit.source: Now, your key vault and key or secret is ready for applications to use.
trans-unit.target: Now, your key vault and key or secret is ready for applications to use.

trans-unit.source: You must authorize applications to use them.
trans-unit.target: You must authorize applications to use them.

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: This step would usually be done by a developer, on a separate computer.
trans-unit.target: This step would usually be done by a developer, on a separate computer.

trans-unit.source: It is not specific to Azure Key Vault, but is included here for completeness.
trans-unit.target: It is not specific to Azure Key Vault, but is included here for completeness.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To complete the tutorial, your account, the vault, and the application that you will register in this step must all be in the same Azure directory.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] To complete the tutorial, your account, the vault, and the application that you will register in this step must all be in the same Azure directory.

trans-unit.source: Applications that use a key vault must authenticate by using a token from Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Applications that use a key vault must authenticate by using a token from Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: To do this, the owner of the application must first register the application in their Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: To do this, the owner of the application must first register the application in their Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the end of registration, the application owner gets the following values:
trans-unit.target: At the end of registration, the application owner gets the following values:

trans-unit.source: An **Application ID** (also known as a Client ID) and **authentication key** (also known as the shared secret).
trans-unit.target: An **Application ID** (also known as a Client ID) and **authentication key** (also known as the shared secret).

trans-unit.source: The application must present both these values to Azure Active Directory, to get a token.
trans-unit.target: The application must present both these values to Azure Active Directory, to get a token.

trans-unit.source: How the application is configured to do this depends on the application.
trans-unit.target: How the application is configured to do this depends on the application.

trans-unit.source: For the Key Vault sample application, the application owner sets these values in the app.config file.
trans-unit.target: For the Key Vault sample application, the application owner sets these values in the app.config file.

trans-unit.source: To register the application in Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: To register the application in Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click **Active Directory**, and then select the directory in which you will register your application.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click **Active Directory**, and then select the directory in which you will register your application.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** You must select the same directory that contains the Azure subscription with which you created your key vault.
trans-unit.target: **Note:** You must select the same directory that contains the Azure subscription with which you created your key vault.

trans-unit.source: If you do not know which directory this is, click **Settings**, identify the subscription with which you created your key vault, and note the name of the directory displayed in the last column.
trans-unit.target: If you do not know which directory this is, click **Settings**, identify the subscription with which you created your key vault, and note the name of the directory displayed in the last column.

trans-unit.source: Click **APPLICATIONS**.
trans-unit.target: Click **APPLICATIONS**.

trans-unit.source: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page shows only the **Add an App** link.
trans-unit.target: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page shows only the **Add an App** link.

trans-unit.source: Click the link, or alternatively, you can click **ADD** on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click the link, or alternatively, you can click **ADD** on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: In the **ADD APPLICATION** wizard, on the **What do you want to do?** page, click **Add an application my organization is developing**.
trans-unit.target: In the **ADD APPLICATION** wizard, on the **What do you want to do?** page, click **Add an application my organization is developing**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Tell us about your application** page, specify a name for your application, and then select **WEB APPLICATION AND/OR WEB API** (the default).
trans-unit.target: On the **Tell us about your application** page, specify a name for your application, and then select **WEB APPLICATION AND/OR WEB API** (the default).

trans-unit.source: Click the **Next** icon.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Next** icon.

trans-unit.source: On the **App properties** page, specify the **SIGN-ON URL** and **APP ID URI** for your web application.
trans-unit.target: On the **App properties** page, specify the **SIGN-ON URL** and **APP ID URI** for your web application.

trans-unit.source: If your application does not have these values, you can make them up for this step (for example, you could specify http://test1.contoso.com for both boxes).
trans-unit.target: If your application does not have these values, you can make them up for this step (for example, you could specify http://test1.contoso.com for both boxes).

trans-unit.source: It does not matter if these sites exist; what is important is that the app ID URI for each application is different for every application in your directory.
trans-unit.target: It does not matter if these sites exist; what is important is that the app ID URI for each application is different for every application in your directory.

trans-unit.source: The directory uses this string to identify your app.
trans-unit.target: The directory uses this string to identify your app.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Complete** icon to save your changes in the wizard.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Complete** icon to save your changes in the wizard.

trans-unit.source: On the **Quick Start** page, click **CONFIGURE**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Quick Start** page, click **CONFIGURE**.

trans-unit.source: Scroll to the **keys** section, select the duration, and then click **SAVE**.
trans-unit.target: Scroll to the **keys** section, select the duration, and then click **SAVE**.

trans-unit.source: The page refreshes and now shows a key value.
trans-unit.target: The page refreshes and now shows a key value.

trans-unit.source: You must configure your application with this key value and the **CLIENT ID** value.
trans-unit.target: You must configure your application with this key value and the **CLIENT ID** value.

trans-unit.source: (Instructions for this configuration will be application-specific.)
trans-unit.target: (Instructions for this configuration will be application-specific.)

trans-unit.source: Copy the client ID value from this page, which you will use in the next step to set permissions on your vault.
trans-unit.target: Copy the client ID value from this page, which you will use in the next step to set permissions on your vault.

trans-unit.source: Authorize the application to use the key or secret
trans-unit.target: Authorize the application to use the key or secret

trans-unit.source: To authorize the application to access the key or secret in the vault, use the
trans-unit.target: To authorize the application to access the key or secret in the vault, use the

trans-unit.source: [Set-AzureKeyVaultAccessPolicy](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903607.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: [Set-AzureKeyVaultAccessPolicy](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903607.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your vault name is **ContosoKeyVault** and the application you want to authorize has a client ID of 8f8c4bbd-485b-45fd-98f7-ec6300b7b4ed, and you want to authorize the application to decrypt and sign with keys in your vault, run the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your vault name is **ContosoKeyVault** and the application you want to authorize has a client ID of 8f8c4bbd-485b-45fd-98f7-ec6300b7b4ed, and you want to authorize the application to decrypt and sign with keys in your vault, run the following:

trans-unit.source: If you want to authorize that same application to read secrets in your vault, run the following:
trans-unit.target: If you want to authorize that same application to read secrets in your vault, run the following:

trans-unit.source: If you want to use a hardware security module (HSM)
trans-unit.target: If you want to use a hardware security module (HSM)

trans-unit.source: For added assurance, you can import or generate keys in hardware security modules (HSMs) that never leave the HSM boundary.
trans-unit.target: For added assurance, you can import or generate keys in hardware security modules (HSMs) that never leave the HSM boundary.

trans-unit.source: The HSMs are FIPS 140-2 Level 2 validated.
trans-unit.target: The HSMs are FIPS 140-2 Level 2 validated.

trans-unit.source: If this requirement doesn't apply to you, skip this section and go to [Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets](#delete).
trans-unit.target: If this requirement doesn't apply to you, skip this section and go to [Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets](#delete).

trans-unit.source: To create these HSM-protected keys, you must have a [vault subscription that supports HSM-protected keys](../../../pricing/free-trial).
trans-unit.target: To create these HSM-protected keys, you must have a [vault subscription that supports HSM-protected keys](../../../pricing/free-trial).

trans-unit.source: When you create the vault, add the **-SKU** parameter:
trans-unit.target: When you create the vault, add the **-SKU** parameter:

trans-unit.source: You can add software-protected keys (as shown earlier) and HSM-protected keys to this vault.
trans-unit.target: You can add software-protected keys (as shown earlier) and HSM-protected keys to this vault.

trans-unit.source: To create an HSM-protected key, set the **-Destination** parameter to 'HSM':
trans-unit.target: To create an HSM-protected key, set the **-Destination** parameter to 'HSM':

trans-unit.source: You can use the following command to import a key from a .PFX file on your computer.
trans-unit.target: You can use the following command to import a key from a .PFX file on your computer.

trans-unit.source: This command imports the key into HSMs in the Key Vault service:
trans-unit.target: This command imports the key into HSMs in the Key Vault service:

trans-unit.source: The next command imports a “bring your own key" (BYOK) package.
trans-unit.target: The next command imports a “bring your own key" (BYOK) package.

trans-unit.source: This lets you generate your key in your local HSM, and transfer it to HSMs in the Key Vault service, without the key leaving the HSM boundary:
trans-unit.target: This lets you generate your key in your local HSM, and transfer it to HSMs in the Key Vault service, without the key leaving the HSM boundary:

trans-unit.source: For more detailed instructions about how to generate this BYOK package, see [How to generate and transfer HSM-protected keys for Azure Key Vault](key-vault-hsm-protected-keys.md).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed instructions about how to generate this BYOK package, see [How to generate and transfer HSM-protected keys for Azure Key Vault](key-vault-hsm-protected-keys.md).

trans-unit.source: Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets
trans-unit.target: Delete the key vault and associated keys and secrets

trans-unit.source: If you no longer need the key vault and the key or secret that it contains, you can delete the key vault by using the [Remove-AzureKeyVault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903603.aspx) cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: If you no longer need the key vault and the key or secret that it contains, you can delete the key vault by using the [Remove-AzureKeyVault](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn903603.aspx) cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Or, you can delete an entire Azure resource group, which includes the key vault and any other resources that you included in that group:
trans-unit.target: Or, you can delete an entire Azure resource group, which includes the key vault and any other resources that you included in that group:

trans-unit.source: Other Azure PowerShell Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Other Azure PowerShell Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Other commands that you might find useful for managing Azure Key Vault:
trans-unit.target: Other commands that you might find useful for managing Azure Key Vault:

trans-unit.source: `$Keys = Get-AzureKeyVaultKey -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`: This command gets a tabular display of all keys and selected properties.
trans-unit.target: `$Keys = Get-AzureKeyVaultKey -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault'`: This command gets a tabular display of all keys and selected properties.

trans-unit.source: `$Keys[0]`: This command displays a full list of properties for the specified key
trans-unit.target: `$Keys[0]`: This command displays a full list of properties for the specified key

trans-unit.source: `Get-AzureKeyVaultSecret`: This command lists a tabular display of all secret names and selected properties.
trans-unit.target: `Get-AzureKeyVaultSecret`: This command lists a tabular display of all secret names and selected properties.

trans-unit.source: `Remove-AzureKeyVaultKey -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault' -Name 'ContosoFirstKey'`: Example how to remove a specific key.
trans-unit.target: `Remove-AzureKeyVaultKey -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault' -Name 'ContosoFirstKey'`: Example how to remove a specific key.

trans-unit.source: `Remove-AzureKeyVaultSecret -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault' -Name 'SQLPassword'`: Example how to remove a specific secret.
trans-unit.target: `Remove-AzureKeyVaultSecret -VaultName 'ContosoKeyVault' -Name 'SQLPassword'`: Example how to remove a specific secret.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps
